header.tag: Ensuring all San Jose residents can access technology and achieve digital literacy.

digital.title: Digital Divide · Digital Inclusion · Digital Equity

carousel.title: Digital Divide - The Problem
carousel.text1: The digital divide describes the increasing gap between those who have affordable access to the technology, digital skills, and support to effectively engage online and people who do not.
carousel.text2: When people cannot access the digital world, they experience barriers to participating in society, such as accessing education, public services and assistance, labor and earning opportunities, and obtaining essential services such as health and financial services. These problems have only been exacerbated by the greater reliance on digital tools since the COVID-19 pandemic.
carousel.caption: In 2020, 10% of Californians reported not having a desktop, laptop, or other computing devices at home. Access was especially limited among low-income (23%), Black (15%), and Latino (15%) households. (Source: PPIC, 2022)

carousel.title: Digital Inclusion - The Work
carousel.text1: Digital inclusion work includes the activities necessary to ensure that all individuals and communities, particularly the most disadvantaged, have equitable access to and use of digital information, digital communication, and other technologies.
carousel.text2: This may look like having affordable and high-speed broadband internet service, internet-capable devices that work for their needs, and having access to digital literacy training and quality technical support.
carousel.caption: In Santa Clara County, roughly a quarter of the county's households don't have access to the internet. (Source: SJ Spotlight)

carousel.title: Digital Equity - The Goal
carousel.text1: Digital equity is the goal in which all individuals and communities have the digital information and technological capacity needed for full participation in our society, democracy, and economy.
carousel.caption: Over 97,000 older Santa Clara County residents do not have access to broadband at home. (Source: Santa Clara County Digital Inclusion Working Group, 2021)

quotes.title: I feel shamed of not being able to help my kids' learning due to lack of even the basic use of a computer.

Some kids didn't have tablets at home. Sometimes, their parents couldn’t afford it. So I think that the school provided tablets for us was probably like a big deal for us, so now we can get work done at home and at school.
If they have no access to the internet, how can they post their resume? Or how can we get to those key jobs? We gotta make sure to get out to those communities and those people that need that.
quotes.desc: --- Shauntrel Brown, Cyber Security Specialist, NPower Graduate

dif_brief.title: What is the San José Digital Inclusion Fund?
dif_brief.pg1: San José aims to close the digital divide through the Digital Inclusion Fund, a $24 million cross-sector fund over a ten-year period. By targeting three key components of digital inclusion (below), San José is committed to connecting 50,000 households to the digital world.
dif_brief.check1: Access programs: providing internet connectivity to residents
dif_brief.check2: Device programs: ensuring every resident has a working device
dif_brief.check3: Digital literacy: enhancing digital skills to access jobs, educational opportunities & critical services
dif_brief.learn_more: Learn more about the San José Digital Inclusion Fund

sj_access.title: SJ Access Services
sj_access.pg1: Through the SJ Access program, the San José Public Library provides residents with the internet access and technology devices they need. At any SJPL library, you can rent a computing or internet device for free with a library card. Check the following cards for more information on the availability, instructions on renting, and return policies of each device.

devices.title: iPad
devices.para: Rent an iPad - a tablet, handheld, portable computer that has a touch-sensitive screen for typing and navigation.

devices.title: Chromebook
devices.para: Access the internet browser through the Chromebook laptop, which runs on the Google Chrome OS.

devices.title: Laptop
devices.para: Check out a laptop, a portable computer for all your digital needs.

hotspot.title: Wi-Fi Hotspot
hotspot.para: Connect to the internet on the move or at home by renting a Wi-Fi hotspot.

self_troubleshooting.title: Self Troubleshooting
self_troubleshooting.para_p1: If you have any problems setting up your device, watch these SJ Access videos, available in English, Spanish, or Vietnamese. For any further issues, you can find tech support
self_troubleshooting.para_p2: , or ask for help at your local San José Public Library branch.
self_troubleshooting.playlist_vi: Full SJ Access Playlist: Tiếng Việt

public_internet_lib.title: Public Free Internet / Find a Library

find_lib.title: Find Your San José Public Library
find_lib.para_p1: All San José Public Library locations are equipped for your digital needs, such as computer rooms, free public Wi-Fi, or hotspot and tech devices available for rent. Please visit our
find_lib.para_p2: page for more information on renting hotspots or computing devices.
find_lib.button_p1: Find your local San José Public Library

public_wifi.title: Free Public Wi-Fi
public_wifi.para_p1: San José currently provides free and unlimited access to the internet at all San José Public Library locations, in downtown San José, and in East San José. The Community Wi-Fi program was officially completed in Fall of 2022. Report any connection issues to SJ 311

cards.title: IN-LIBRARY WI-FI
cards.para: All San José Public Library locations have free Wi-Fi internet access 24/7.

cards.title: DOWNTOWN WI-FI
cards.para: Free public Wi-Fi is available in certain popular corridors in Downtown San José.

cards.title: EAST SAN JOSÉ WI-FI
cards.para: An outdoor Wi-Fi network with strong access near local high schools.

broadband.title: Wired - Broadband Plan
broadband.tagline: Find an affordable home internet plan that works for you.
broadband.subtitle: Affordable Broadband Plans
broadband.para: If you need an affordable home internet plan for you or your household, check out these flyers for instructions on determining your eligibility and signing up for a plan. If you are a San José resident and need assistance with connecting to affordable internet at home, please call (408) 716-3811 and you will be transferred to an organization that can assist you.

digital_literacy.title: Digital Literacy Training
digital_literacy.para: Why learn how to go online? Digital literacy skills allow people to participate in activities such as staying connected to families and friends, accessing healthcare, education, and transportation, and finding reliable information.
digital_literacy.tagline: San José provides several resources for everyone to gain digital skills:

cards.title: Classes at SJPL
cards.para: Take hybrid (can join in-person or online) computer classes through your local San José Public Library:

cards.title: Self-Paced, Online Courses
cards.para: Take an online digital literacy course in your own language, at your own pace:

people.title: In-Person Help
people.para: Find in-person or one-on-one support for your technical questions and needs.

cards.title: 1) In-Library Support
cards.para: Find your local San José Public Library through our map, and ask staff for in-person tech support.

cards.title: 2) Technical Support Event
cards.para: Sign up for a Tech Support event or appointment at your library. These events might take place in-peson, virtually or in a hybrid-model.

cards.title: 3) Community Organizations
cards.para: Contact any of these local organizations that can help you with your digital needs.

cards.title: 4) Tech Support Helpline
cards.para: Call the Tech Support Helpline at:
cards.para1: (408) 808-2000 Monday-Saturday from 11:00 AM to 6:00 PM if you need support in English or Spanish.

questions1.title: What has the Digital Inclusion Fund accomplished?
questions1.info: Visit our Learn More page to learn about DIF's accomplishments!

questions1.title: Who can receive funding from the Digital Inclusion Fund?
questions1.info: Any organization that is a 501(c)(3), public agency, or educational institution that serves San José residents can receive funding from the Digital Inclusion Fund. Please visit the Apply to the Digital Inclusion Fund page for more information on the application process.
questions1.page1Name: Apply to the Digital Inclusion Fund

questions1.title: What organizations have previously been funded by the Digital Inclusion Fund?
questions1.info: Visit the Grantees & Supporters section of our Learn More page to learn about precious organizations funded by the DIF.

questions1.title: How do I apply to the Digital Inclusion Fund?
questions1.info: Updated information for open applications is available on the Apply to the Digital Inclusion Fund page.
questions1.page1Name: Apply to the Digital Inclusion Fund

questions1.title: Can individuals receive funding from the Digital Inclusion Fund?
questions1.info: Unfortunately no, sorry! However, if you need financial help getting digital resources (i.e. getting an internet plan, finding a device), please visit our SJ Access page for resources from the library or contact one of our partner organizations who can help you directly.

questions2.title: Do I need a San José Public Library card to rent a device?
questions2.info: Yes, you need a physical SJPL card (not an e-Library card) to borrow SJ Access Wi-Fi hotspots, laptops, and other tech devices.  Click below for more information on how to get your SJPL library card and other available resources.

questions2.title: If I live outside of San José, can I still rent devices from the library?
questions2.info: Yes! Anyone living in California can get a San José Public Library card that allows you to borrow internet hotspots and computing devices, and sign up for computer classes.

questions2.title: Where is the nearest library to me?
questions2.info: Click below to find the closest San José Public Library to you!
